response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to ensure the payment for debt service for the revenue bonds and the continued availability of resources for the cancer research center of Hawaii's research and operations. This is achieved by increasing the cigarette tax from sixteen cents to eighteen cents and amending the disposition of cigarette tax revenues by allocating the increase in the cigarette tax amount to the Hawaii cancer research special fund. The bill amends the tax rate effective January 1, 2026, and the Act itself has an effective date of December 31, 2050.",
  "appropriations": "This bill amends the disposition of cigarette tax revenues rather than making a direct appropriation. After December 31, 2025, the measure allocates 4.0 cents per cigarette to the Hawaii cancer research special fund for \"research and operating expenses and for capital expenditures.\" Other allocations include 1.125 cents per cigarette, but \"no more than $7,400,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) in a fiscal year,\" to the trauma system special fund, and 1.25 cents per cigarette, but \"no more than $8,800,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) in a fiscal year,\" to both the community health centers special fund and the emergency medical services special fund.",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The fiscal impact is based on the assumption that an increase in the cigarette tax and a reallocation of the resulting revenues will address a financial shortfall. The legislature finds that a \"decline in smoking has resulted in a decrease of over fifty per cent in cigarette tax revenues to the Hawaii cancer research special fund,\" which \"jeopardizes the revenue stream for debt service for the revenue bonds.\" The methodology involves increasing the tax per cigarette from 16.00 to 18.00 cents and directing the additional revenue to the special fund to ensure its solvency.",
  "agency_impact": "The Department of Taxation will be responsible for implementing and collecting the increased excise tax on cigarettes beginning January 1, 2026. The University of Hawaii Cancer Center will see increased funding allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund to support its operations and debt service. The Department of Health will continue to administer the trauma system, community health centers, and emergency medical services special funds, with revenues subject to the specified annual caps.",
  "economic_impact": "This Act is intended to ensure the \"continued availability of resources for the cancer research center of Hawaii to deliver cutting-edge cancer treatments to the State's cancer patients.\" By stabilizing the revenue stream for the cancer center, the measure supports its ability to conduct vital research and maintain its status as one of only seventy-two National Cancer Institute-designated cancer centers. The legislature notes that the decline in smoking is a \"public health victory\" but has paradoxically created a financial challenge that this bill seeks to remedy.",
  "policy_impact": "This bill amends Section 245-3 and Section 245-15 of the Hawaii Revised Statutes. It alters state tax policy by increasing the excise tax paid by every wholesaler or dealer for each cigarette sold, used, or possessed. The Act also modifies state fiscal policy by amending the disposition of these revenues, increasing the allocation to the Hawaii cancer research special fund and setting caps on allocations to other health-related special funds.",
  "revenue_sources": "The revenue source is the excise tax on cigarettes and other tobacco products. The bill specifies that \"Every wholesaler or dealer, in addition to any other taxes provided by law, shall pay... an excise tax.\" This measure increases the tax to \"18.00 cents for each cigarette or little cigar sold, used, or possessed by a wholesaler or dealer on and after January 1, 2026.\" All moneys collected are paid into the state treasury as state realizations before being allocated according to the statute.",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "Beginning January 1, 2026, this bill increases the excise tax from 16.00 cents to 18.00 cents for each cigarette. The disposition of these revenues will be amended after December 31, 2025. The allocation to the Hawaii cancer research special fund will increase from 2.0 cents to 4.0 cents per cigarette. This additional funding is for research, operating expenses, capital expenditures, and specifically for \"debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance\" until June 30, 2041. The trauma system special fund is set to receive 1.125 cents per cigarette, but \"no more than $7,400,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) in a fiscal year.\" The community health centers special fund will receive 1.25 cents per cigarette, but \"no more than $8,800,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) in a fiscal year.\" Similarly, the emergency medical services special fund will receive 1.25 cents per cigarette, capped at \"no more than $8,800,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) in a fiscal year.\" These changes are designed to provide a stable, long-term revenue stream for the cancer research fund over the next six years and beyond. The department is required to provide an annual accounting of these dispositions to the legislature.",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The measure is expected to increase state operating revenues from the cigarette tax effective January 1, 2026. The tax increase from 16.00 to 18.00 cents per cigarette will generate additional revenue for the state. These increased funds are specifically allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund to address a significant decline in its revenues.",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The bill provides direct funding for capital expenditures related to the University of Hawaii Cancer Center. Revenue deposited into the Hawaii cancer research special fund is designated for \"research and operating expenses and for capital expenditures.\" Furthermore, from January 1, 2026, until June 30, 2041, a portion of the allocation \"shall be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance.\"",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The fiscal implications of this bill are ongoing and will continue after the initial six-year period. The cigarette tax rate of 18.00 cents per cigarette and the new revenue disposition formula are permanent changes effective January 1, 2026. The Hawaii cancer research special fund will continue to receive 4.0 cents per cigarette, while the trauma system, community health centers, and emergency medical services special funds will continue to receive their allocations up to their respective annual caps of $7,400,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) and $8,800,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt).",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "No previous fiscal note was provided for comparison."
}

parts.text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to ensure the payment for debt service for the revenue bonds and the continued availability of resources for the cancer research center of Hawaii's research and operations. This is achieved by increasing the cigarette tax from sixteen cents to eighteen cents and amending the disposition of cigarette tax revenues by allocating the increase in the cigarette tax amount to the Hawaii cancer research special fund. The bill amends the tax rate effective January 1, 2026, and the Act itself has an effective date of December 31, 2050.",
  "appropriations": "This bill amends the disposition of cigarette tax revenues rather than making a direct appropriation. After December 31, 2025, the measure allocates 4.0 cents per cigarette to the Hawaii cancer research special fund for \"research and operating expenses and for capital expenditures.\" Other allocations include 1.125 cents per cigarette, but \"no more than $7,400,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) in a fiscal year,\" to the trauma system special fund, and 1.25 cents per cigarette, but \"no more than $8,800,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) in a fiscal year,\" to both the community health centers special fund and the emergency medical services special fund.",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The fiscal impact is based on the assumption that an increase in the cigarette tax and a reallocation of the resulting revenues will address a financial shortfall. The legislature finds that a \"decline in smoking has resulted in a decrease of over fifty per cent in cigarette tax revenues to the Hawaii cancer research special fund,\" which \"jeopardizes the revenue stream for debt service for the revenue bonds.\" The methodology involves increasing the tax per cigarette from 16.00 to 18.00 cents and directing the additional revenue to the special fund to ensure its solvency.",
  "agency_impact": "The Department of Taxation will be responsible for implementing and collecting the increased excise tax on cigarettes beginning January 1, 2026. The University of Hawaii Cancer Center will see increased funding allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund to support its operations and debt service. The Department of Health will continue to administer the trauma system, community health centers, and emergency medical services special funds, with revenues subject to the specified annual caps.",
  "economic_impact": "This Act is intended to ensure the \"continued availability of resources for the cancer research center of Hawaii to deliver cutting-edge cancer treatments to the State's cancer patients.\" By stabilizing the revenue stream for the cancer center, the measure supports its ability to conduct vital research and maintain its status as one of only seventy-two National Cancer Institute-designated cancer centers. The legislature notes that the decline in smoking is a \"public health victory\" but has paradoxically created a financial challenge that this bill seeks to remedy.",
  "policy_impact": "This bill amends Section 245-3 and Section 245-15 of the Hawaii Revised Statutes. It alters state tax policy by increasing the excise tax paid by every wholesaler or dealer for each cigarette sold, used, or possessed. The Act also modifies state fiscal policy by amending the disposition of these revenues, increasing the allocation to the Hawaii cancer research special fund and setting caps on allocations to other health-related special funds.",
  "revenue_sources": "The revenue source is the excise tax on cigarettes and other tobacco products. The bill specifies that \"Every wholesaler or dealer, in addition to any other taxes provided by law, shall pay... an excise tax.\" This measure increases the tax to \"18.00 cents for each cigarette or little cigar sold, used, or possessed by a wholesaler or dealer on and after January 1, 2026.\" All moneys collected are paid into the state treasury as state realizations before being allocated according to the statute.",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "Beginning January 1, 2026, this bill increases the excise tax from 16.00 cents to 18.00 cents for each cigarette. The disposition of these revenues will be amended after December 31, 2025. The allocation to the Hawaii cancer research special fund will increase from 2.0 cents to 4.0 cents per cigarette. This additional funding is for research, operating expenses, capital expenditures, and specifically for \"debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance\" until June 30, 2041. The trauma system special fund is set to receive 1.125 cents per cigarette, but \"no more than $7,400,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) in a fiscal year.\" The community health centers special fund will receive 1.25 cents per cigarette, but \"no more than $8,800,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) in a fiscal year.\" Similarly, the emergency medical services special fund will receive 1.25 cents per cigarette, capped at \"no more than $8,800,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) in a fiscal year.\" These changes are designed to provide a stable, long-term revenue stream for the cancer research fund over the next six years and beyond. The department is required to provide an annual accounting of these dispositions to the legislature.",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The measure is expected to increase state operating revenues from the cigarette tax effective January 1, 2026. The tax increase from 16.00 to 18.00 cents per cigarette will generate additional revenue for the state. These increased funds are specifically allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund to address a significant decline in its revenues.",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The bill provides direct funding for capital expenditures related to the University of Hawaii Cancer Center. Revenue deposited into the Hawaii cancer research special fund is designated for \"research and operating expenses and for capital expenditures.\" Furthermore, from January 1, 2026, until June 30, 2041, a portion of the allocation \"shall be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance.\"",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The fiscal implications of this bill are ongoing and will continue after the initial six-year period. The cigarette tax rate of 18.00 cents per cigarette and the new revenue disposition formula are permanent changes effective January 1, 2026. The Hawaii cancer research special fund will continue to receive 4.0 cents per cigarette, while the trauma system, community health centers, and emergency medical services special funds will continue to receive their allocations up to their respective annual caps of $7,400,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt) and $8,800,000 (HB441_.HTM.txt).",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "No previous fiscal note was provided for comparison."
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: HB441 SD2 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 441 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 2 STATE OF HAWAII S.D. 2 A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO CIGARETTE TAXES . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: SECTION 1. The legislature finds that since the inception of the

1. The legislature finds that since the inception of the cigarette tax in the State, cigarette tax revenue has funded vital health care services in the State, including cancer research and prevention, the State's trauma system, community health centers, and emergency medical services. Before 2006, all cigarette tax revenue was

emergency medical services. Before 2006, all cigarette tax revenue was directed to the State's general fund, indirectly supporting health initiatives. However, with the passage of Act 316, Session Laws of Hawaii 2006, which included an increase in the cigarette tax, the legislature formally recognized the importance of allocating increased amounts

the legislature formally recognized the importance of allocating increased amounts of cigarette tax revenues to programs that strive to maintain public health in the State, such as the cancer research center of Hawaii, the State's emergency medical services, critically needed trauma centers, and community health centers. The legislature believes these

trauma centers, and community health centers. The legislature believes these programs are the most appropriate and effective use of cigarette tax revenues to help the greatest number of people in the State. The legislature further finds that financial support for research into the causes and treatment of cancer is especially

research into the causes and treatment of cancer is especially critical now that cancer diagnoses in the United States for 2024 are expected to surpass two million for the first time in history. In the State, an average of 7,393 local residents are diagnosed with invasive cancer, leading to 2,393

local residents are diagnosed with invasive cancer, leading to 2,393 deaths each year. Nearly forty per cent of today's adult population will experience cancer in their lifetimes. The cancer research center of Hawaii, also known as the university of Hawaii cancer center, is one of only seventy-two National Cancer Institute

cancer center, is one of only seventy-two National Cancer Institute (NCI)-designated cancer centers in the United States. A NCI‑designation is a mark of excellence, requiring the cancer research center of Hawaii to meet rigorous standards for transdisciplinary, state-of-the-art research focused on developing new and better approaches to preventing, diagnosing, and

on developing new and better approaches to preventing, diagnosing, and treating cancer. Furthermore, the cancer research center of Hawaii is also the only NCI-designated cancer center serving the State and the Pacific. It is the only cancer center studying cancer causes and treatments in the diverse ethnic groups found in

causes and treatments in the diverse ethnic groups found in Hawaii and the Pacific, such as Native Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders. The legislature additionally finds that a portion of the cigarette tax revenue currently allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund is specifically pledged towards revenue bonds sold to

special fund is specifically pledged towards revenue bonds sold to construct the cancer center in 2010, conduct cancer research, and fund its operations. Due to successful public education, strong anti-smoking policies, and increased costs to cigarettes, the decline in smoking rates is a public health victory. However, paradoxically, this decline

rates is a public health victory. However, paradoxically, this decline in smoking has resulted in a decrease of over fifty per cent in cigarette tax revenues to the Hawaii cancer research special fund. This decline jeopardizes the revenue stream for debt service for the revenue bonds and diminishes the availability

debt service for the revenue bonds and diminishes the availability of resources for the cancer research center of Hawaii to deliver cutting-edge cancer treatments to the State's cancer patients. Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to ensure the payment for debt service for the revenue bonds and the continued

for debt service for the revenue bonds and the continued availability of resources for the cancer research center of Hawaii's research and operations by: (1) Increasing the cigarette tax from sixteen cents to eighteen cents; and (2) Amending the disposition of cigarette tax revenues by allocating the increase in the

of cigarette tax revenues by allocating the increase in the cigarette tax amount to the Hawaii cancer research special fund. SECTION 2 . Section 245-3, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by amending subsection (a) to read as follows: "(a) Every wholesaler or dealer, in addition to any other taxes provided

wholesaler or dealer, in addition to any other taxes provided by law, shall pay, for the privilege of conducting business and other activities in the State, an excise tax equal to: (1) 5.00 cents for each cigarette sold, used, or possessed by a wholesaler or dealer after June 30, 1998,

possessed by a wholesaler or dealer after June 30, 1998, whether or not sold at wholesale, or if not sold, then at the same rate upon the use by the wholesaler or dealer; (2) 6.00 cents for each cigarette sold, used, or possessed by a wholesaler or dealer after September

used, or possessed by a wholesaler or dealer after September 30, 2002, whether or not sold at wholesale, or if not sold, then at the same rate upon the use by the wholesaler or dealer; (3) 6.50 cents for each cigarette sold, used, or possessed by a wholesaler or dealer

cigarette sold, used, or possessed by a wholesaler or dealer after June 30, 2003, whether or not sold at wholesale, or if not sold, then at the same rate upon the use by the wholesaler or dealer; (4) 7.00 cents for each cigarette sold, used, or possessed by a wholesaler

for each cigarette sold, used, or possessed by a wholesaler or dealer after June 30, 2004, whether or not sold at wholesale, or if not sold, then at the same rate upon the use by the wholesaler or dealer; (5) 8.00 cents for each cigarette sold, used, or p

numbers_data.text: and [ thereafter: ] prior to July 1, 2025: (A) 2.0 cents per cigarette shall be deposited to the credit of the Hawaii cancer research special fund, established pursuant to section 304A-2168, for research and operating expenses and for capital expenditures; (B) 1.125 cents per cigarette, but not more than $7,400,000 in a fiscal year, shall be deposited to the credit of the trauma system special fund established pursuant to section 321-22.5; (C) 1.25 cents per cigarette, but not more than $8,800,000 in a fiscal year, shall be deposited to the credit of the community health centers special fund established pursuant

The department shall provide an annual accounting of these dispositions to the legislature. " SECTION 3. Statutory material to be repealed is bracketed and stricken. New statutory material
